chapter.title: Stereotypes
chapter.para: The CDI specification defines a stereotype as follows:

blockquote.para: In many systems, use of architectural patterns produces a set of recurring bean roles. A stereotype allows a framework developer to identify such a role and declare some common metadata for beans with that role in a central place.

A stereotype can also specify that:

all beans with the stereotype are alternatives.

blockquote.para: A bean can declare zero, one or multiple stereotypes. Stereotype annotations can be applied to a bean class or producer method or field.

Naturally, overriding a single default is not much use. But remember, stereotypes can define more than just the default scope.

section.title: Interceptor bindings for stereotypes
section.para: A stereotype can specify a set of interceptor bindings to be inherited by all beans with that stereotype.
This helps us to separate technical concerns, like transactions and security, even further from business code.

section.title: Name defaulting with stereotypes
section.para: We can specify that all beans with a certain stereotype have a defaulted EL name when a name is not explicitly defined for that bean. All we need to do is add an empty @Named annotation:
Now, the LoginAction bean will have the defaulted name loginAction.

section.title: Alternative stereotypes
section.para: A stereotype can indicate that all beans to which it is applied are @Alternatives. An alternative stereotype lets us classify beans by deployment scenario.
We can apply an alternative stereotype to a whole set of beans, and activate them all with one line of code in beans.xml.

section.title: Stereotype stacking
section.para: Stereotypes can declare other stereotypes, which is known as stereotype stacking. This is useful when you have two distinct stereotypes which are meaningful on their own, but in other situations may be meaningful when combined.

section.title: Built-in stereotypes
section.para: We have already met two standard stereotypes defined by the CDI specification: @Interceptor and @Decorator.
CDI defines one further standard stereotype, @Model, which is expected to be used frequently in web applications:
Instead of using JSF managed beans, just annotate a bean @Model, and use it directly in your JSF view.
